items.message:

River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 24/02/25.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
We expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday, 25/02/24.

To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high, but stable on the River Windrush. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in areas close to the river around Bourton on the Water. Further showers are forecast for today and tomorrow. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days and to remain responsive to further rainfall. 
Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated Tuesday morning, 25/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels have risen overnight at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this morning and during Monday.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  River levels are still rising.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  And stay aware in case further warnings are issued.
This message will be updated on 25/02/25, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising slowly in response to rainfall overnight last night and this morning. River levels are currently below the alert thresholds, however flooding remains possible today, Monday 24th February. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 10am tomorrow morning, 25/02/25.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station has risen and is now 8.87m. The drain level at the station has also risen and is currently 7.24m 
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and the road from Muchelney to Draycott above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m.
Pumping is taking place at Huish Episcopi pumping station when possible. Pumping is continuing to clear water from the moors as quickly as possible and is under review.
Staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on road closures.
This message will be updated by 11am on 25/02/2025, or as the situation changes

items.description: Middle Stour from Hammoon to Sturminster Marshall
items.message:
Rising river levels are causing flooding throughout the afternoon.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Dorset Stour, Lower Dorset Stour, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Hammoon, Bere Marsh, Stourpaine, Durweston and Lower Blandford St Mary.

Further flooding is expected this afternoon and into the evening as river levels are rising due to heavy rainfall last night.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Activate any property flood protection products you may have. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Refer to local authority website for road closures. Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 25/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

The water level in the River Blackwater at Ower and Cadnam River is high and rising. In the last 24 hours, 18mm of rain has been recorded at Romsey. This total, while not large, has simply added to a river which was already high, as a result of rain over the last week. From 08:30 this morning (24/02/2025), the river will flood land, fields and roads at Cadnam, West Wellow, Landford and Ower. Water levels will also be very high around the mill building at East Wellow. Rain is forecast to clear the area by 10:00 this morning (24/02/2025). The river will peak at around 14:00 this afternoon (24/02/2025). There is a small possibility that by 12:00, a Flood Warning will be issued for onset of isolated property flooding. We continue to monitor the forecast. Our operations staff will work to ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure that pumps used to protect property are operating correctly. This Flood Alert will be updated by 11:00 on Tuesday 25/02/2025 or sooner, if we think property flooding will occur.

items.message:

There is also likely to be flooding at the Middle & Lower parts of the River Brue  with the lower Brue bank being full. Lovington to Highbridge, Low-lying properties need to be aware. Overtopping can occur at lower levels when banks of lower reaches are full from previous flood.

Further isolated heavy rain is forecast for today until 10AM with rivers potentially reacting. However, the rest of the day remains relatively dry. 

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and checking rivers for blockages. Consider acting on your flood plan if you have one. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 9AM on 25/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Landford to Wade Bridge on the River Blackwater
items.message: The water level in the River Blackwater at Wellow and Ower is high and rising. In the last 24 hours, 19.4mm of rainfall has been recorded in Romsey. This total, whilst not that large, has simply added to a river which is already high as a result of rainfall recorded over the last few days. Over the next 12 - 24 hours, more significant out of bank flooding will affect land and roads from at West Wellow, Landford and Ower. 11:30 this morning, Monday (24/02/2024), the river will be high enough to flood the Mill at East Wellow. Rain has now cleared the area. The river will peak at around 14:00 this afternoon (24/02/2025). Our operations staff are ensuring the River Blackwater is kept free of blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please take appropriate action to protect property and ensure pumps used to lower water levels are operating. This Flood Warning will be updated by 10:00 on 25/02/2025.

items.message:
Overnight we have seen continuous rainfall in the River Eden area. This has meant that the River Eden is now rising.
The main areas of concern are The Rivers Eden, Eden Brook and Kent Ditch from Blindley Heath to Penshurst including Edenbridge and Hever, there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from 09:30 today 24/02/2025.
We expect the river to remain high throughout today though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not expected to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for, and clearing, blockages in this location. This message will be updated this evening or earlier if the situation changes.

12mm of rain was measured Monday morning. Minor flood impacts are expected to affect fields, roads, and gardens. The Cuckmere River through Hellingly is now peaking, and will soon begin to fall. The Bull River in Hellingly will continue rising for longer. From 13:00 Monday 24/02/2025 minor flood impacts could affect gardens on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. From 18:00 24/02/2025 minor flooding could also affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, and fields near Alfriston. Only a small amount of rain is forecast Monday afternoon and next week. In Hellingly, all rivers should begin to fall by 20:00 24/02/2025, and be nearer to a normal level by Tuesday afternoon. In Alfriston, the river will fall by 04:00 25/02/2025, and might not return nearer to a normal level until the weekend. A lot of rain and more flood risk could be possible Wednesday. Plan to avoid driving routes that flood, including Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly and North Street Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 14:00 on 25/02/2025.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

20mm of rain is forecast Sunday night. If as much rain falls as predicted, flooding could be possible. From 04:00 on Monday 24/02/25, flooding could affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach  riverside properties through Buxted, near the White Hart pub and areas around Hempstead Mill on Hempstead Lane, Uckfield. Areas in Uckfield most at risk include: The Roller Mill, Mill Lane, River Way, Bridge Cottage & Bell Walk. From 09:00 on Monday 24/02/25 flood water could approach properties at Isfield Mill and Isfield Bridge. Only isolated showers are forecast on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. The river should begin to fall by 11:00 on Monday 24/02/25 in Buxted and by 16:00 in Isfield. The River Uck will remain higher than normal until Tuesday afternoon. River levels could end up higher than on Saturday, maybe similar to 28/01/2025. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Buxted and Isfield, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 19:00 on 24/02/25.

The Western Rother is high following Monday morning's rain. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens on Station Road, Liss, and Mill Lane and Old Mill Lane, Sheet. From 11:00 Monday 24/02/2025, minor flooding could also affect gardens in Iping, Stedham and Midhurst. From 16:00 24/02/2025, flood water will be very close to and approach properties at Lodsbridge, near Selham. From 22:00 24/02/2025, flooding could affect properties at Fittleworth Mill, and nearby properties. The Lod is also high, and flooding could affect Lickfold Bridge, Highstead Lane and at Halfway Bridge. River levels could peak higher than 28/01/2025. Only scattered showers are forecast Monday afternoon and Tuesday. The river is already falling in Liss, and should begin to fall by 17:00 24/02/2025 in Midhurst, and by 12:00 25/02/2025 in Fittleworth. More rain and flood risk could be possible on Wednesday. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 25/02/2025.

17mm of rain fell overnight on Sunday (23/02/2025). The River Adur is high and slowly rising. Minor flooding could continue to affect the A281, at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as extensive water in fields, flooding could also affect gardens of properties near Mock Bridge. Only isolated showers are forecast on Tuesday and Wednesday. The river should begin to fall by 23:00 on Monday 24/02/2025, but will be higher than normal until Tuesday afternoon. Land will remain flooded over the next few days. There is uncertainty, but a lot of rain could be possible on Wednesday, which could cause flood risk to return. Some roads, including the A281, at Mock Bridge, may be affected by flooding. Please take care driving on routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 14:00 on 25/02/2025.

The River Ouse is high and rising. 20mm of rain has been recorded at Ardingly on Monday morning. From 13:00 on Monday 24/02/2025, minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads and gardens at Lindfield Bridge on the B2028, near Lindfield. Flood water could affect gardens on Sloop Lane. Roads at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge will be affected. From 14:00 on 24/02/2025, flooding could affect the Anchor Inn and gardens of properties at Barcombe Mills. Barcombe Mills road is likely to be affected by flood water. River levels could end up similar to 28/01/2025. Only showers are forecast Monday afternoon and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall by 20:00 on Monday 24/02/2025 near Ardingly, but not until 10:00 on Tuesday 25/02/2025 near Barcombe. On Wednesday it is possible another 30mm of rain could occur. River levels could remain higher than normal all week. Please plan to avoid driving on routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 12:00 25/02/2025

River levels are high and rising at the Hammoon river gauge on the River Stour as a result of overnight heavy rainfall.  Flooding of low-lying land, roads and farmland is possible. There is a possibility of flooding for tributaries between Sturminster Newton and Wimborne.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, consider installing property flood resilience equipment, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from 4:00pm today, Monday 24th February, and for at least the next 24hrs.  This is due to a natural tide locking effect, and tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth which is restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide.  We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time.  Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 11:00am tomorrow morning, Tuesday 25th February, or as the situation changes.

We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated on 25/02/25 by 12 noon, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Kennet, River Og, River Aldbourne, Froxfield Stream, River Dun, River Shalbourne

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but still within banks along most of the Upper Kennet and its tributaries. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, particularly in areas close to the River Dun near Hungerford where river levels are high but stable. Further showers are forecast for today and tomorrow  We expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the next few days. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated Tuesday morning, 25/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lambourn and its tributaries from Upper Lambourn down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Lambourn, Great Shefford Stream, Winterbourne Stream

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high on the Winterbourne Stream in Bagnor and the River Lambourn in Newbury. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue and we expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the next few days. Further showers are forecast for today and tomorrow. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated Tuesday morning, 25/02/25, or as the situation changes.

23mm of rain has fallen overnight (23/02/2025). Minor flooding could continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens along the length of the river Lox, and approach properties near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane, and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. Flood water may also affect isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold, and the gardens of riverside properties on Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. Only isolated showers are forecast on Tuesday and Wednesday. The river should begin to fall by 23:00 on Monday 24/02/2025, but will be higher than normal until Tuesday afternoon. Flood impacts should begin to slowly ease when river levels start to fall. Please continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst, to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 14:00 on 25/02/2025.

The River Adur is high, but now falling, following Monday morning's rain. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens between Coolham and Henfield. Only isolated showers are forecast on Monday afternoon and Tuesday. The river should continue to fall, but will be higher than normal until Tuesday morning. There is uncertainty, but a lot of rain could be possible on Wednesday, which could cause flood risk to return. Some roads, including the Coolham road at Slaughter Bridge, may be affected by flooding. Please take care driving on routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 14:00 25/02/2025.

items.description: River Darent from Westerham to Dartford
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible this morning, 24/02/2025.
No property flooding is expected.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads along the River Darent particularly around Westerham. The river level is expected to peak by midday. Weather conditions are expected to improve this afternoon and no further flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation and clearing debris from weed screens.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 5 PM on 24/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Littlemead Brook, Cranleigh Waters, Hascombe Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are rising  on the Cranleigh Waters as a result of heavy rainfall, especially in the Flash Bridge area. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today. 

Further heavy rainfall is forecast today, with lighter rainfall tomorrow. We are monitoring the situation. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 25/02/25, or as the situation changes.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely from this afternoon Monday 24th February 2025 and for the next 24 hours.  River levels are responding to the recent rainfall.  Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas, including Lordship Lane and Cow Watering Lane around Writtle College.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time.  The forecast is for some showers over the next couple of days but mainly dry conditions today, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal.  Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We are monitoring the situation and will update this message tomorrow morning, Tuesday 25th February, or as the situation changes.

The River Arun is high and rising following Monday's rain. Near Horsham, river levels are nearly peaking. Only minimal flood impacts are expected to affect gardens of Tanbridge Park and Blackbridge Court. From 14:00 24/02/2025 small amounts of flood water could affect gardens of isolated mill properties near Broadbridge Heath. From 22:00 24/02/2025 flood water could affect gardens of properties at Pallingham Lock. River levels will probably peak lower than Saturday. Only scattered showers are forecast Monday afternoon and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall by 18:00 24/02/2025 near Broadbridge Heath, returning to a normal level by Tuesday afternoon. Near Pallingham, the river should begin to fall by 10:00 25/02/2025, but will be higher than normal all week. There is uncertainty, but a lot of rain and more flood risk could be possible Wednesday. Please keep flood protection products installed in Wanford, if you have them. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to reduce flood risk in Horsham. We will update this message by 15:00 25/02/2025.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is possible this afternoon on 24/02/2025.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads along the River Medway particularly footpaths and riverside areas in the Maidstone area. 
Further flooding is possible this evening as river levels are expected to remain high due to rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation and clearing debris from weed screens.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 25/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

A month's rain (70mm) has been recorded in the past week. The River Arun is high, but currently falling at Pulborough. Water will continue to be in fields. The River Arun is expected to rise again Monday evening, and from 06:00 Tuesday 25/02/2025 could affect gardens, the A29, and approach properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough, near to Swan Bridge and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. As tide levels are currently low, no property flooding is expected in Amberley or Arundel. Water is expected to be closer to the tops of the bank from Wednesday, as tide levels will rise this week. River levels will probably peak lower than on 28/01/2025. Only a small amount of rain is forecast Monday afternoon, and Tuesday. The river should again fall by 10:00 26/02/2025, but will remain higher than normal all week. A lot of rain and more flood risk could be possible Wednesday. Please keep flood protection products installed in Pulborough, Amberley and Arundel, if you have them. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 16:00 on 25/02/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message: Groundwater levels remain high and are still reactive to further rainfall. Areas at risk include areas around the Till and the Wylye Valley. Flooding of roads and fields is possible. We are expecting some further rainfall in the coming days, although with low daily totals.  Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 25/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Ehen, Calder, Irt and Esk

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ehen, Rive Calder, River Irt, River Esk

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high but currently stable at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. 

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter period.  Low-lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 25/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high but currently stable at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourne Valley.  

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter.  Low lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 25/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford are high but relatively stable. During the last week, the weather has been dry. A small number of properties are expected to be experiencing cellar flooding in Preston Candover and Old Alresford. Septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively. From today 17/02/2025 to Friday 21/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are forecast, with up to 15mm possible across these 5 days. Groundwater levels will remain stable initially, before beginning to slowly fall later in the week. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 24/02/2025.

Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 26th February 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 26th February 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high and continuing to rise slowly at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton. 

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter period. Low-lying land and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 25/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Avon from Didworthy to Aveton Gifford
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Avon has reduced.  River levels are falling below levels of concern and no further property flooding is expected.

Groundwater levels in Hursley are high and rising slowly. During the last week, nearly a month’s rain (56mm) has been recorded at Otterbourne. During this time, the level at Hursley has risen by 16cm. Most of the village are now expected to be experiencing cellar flooding and sewerage system impacts. From today 24/02/2025, to Friday 28/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are expected. However, there is a small possibility that heavy rain (up to 45mm) may affect the area on Wednesday (26/02/2025). Groundwater levels are expected to rise over the next week. Internal ground floor flooding is possible in the next 7 days. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 03/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: In the villages surrounding Andover, groundwater levels are high and relatively stable. In the last week, over half a month’s rain (32mm) has been recorded at Andover. Cellar flooding is expected to be ongoing in Appleshaw and Hatherden, and is possible in Penton Grafton. Groundwater is flooding the main road into Penton Grafton and is emerging into Deacon and Down Road, Kimpton. Impacts to the sewerage systems in Penton Mewsey and Appleshaw are ongoing. From today 24/02/2025, to Friday 28/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are expected. However, there is a small possibility that heavy rain (up to 45mm) may affect the area on Wednesday (26/02/2025). If the heavier rain in the forecast affects the area, then groundwater levels will rise and cellar flooding in Kimpton and surface water flood risk in Thruxton could occur in the next 2 weeks. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 03/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: Groundwater levels in Deane and Ashe are high and rising slowly. In the last week, over half a month’s rain (40mm) has been recorded at Overton. During this time, the level at Oakley has risen by 13cm. In Deane, cellar flooding is expected to be ongoing. Groundwater will be affecting the ability of septic tanks to operate effectively. From today 24/02/2025, to Friday 28/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are expected. However, there is a small possibility that heavy rain (up to 45mm) may affect the area on Wednesday (26/02/2025). Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising well into March in response to the rain already recorded this week. In early-March, it is possible that the access road from the B3400 into Deane (at Deane Park) will need to be closed. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. We will update this Flood Alert by 18:00 on Monday 03/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Henley and Assendon area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are continuing to rise slowly at our Stonor borehole near Henley and Assendon. 

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding.  We expect levels to remain high for the rest of the winter.  Low lying land, roads and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 25/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

Groundwater levels in Salisbury Plain are high although they have been dropping and we are expecting levels to keep dropping, but this will be slow as we are expecting some further rainfall in the coming days, although with low daily totals. The groundwater level at the Tilshead borehole is currently 98.83m.  Areas that could be affected include: Tilshead, Orcheston, Shrewton and Berwick St James. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures over the weekend and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 25/02/2025.

items.description: Upper Wylye from Brixton Deverill to Warminster
items.message:
River levels are high and rising on the Upper River Wylye from Brixton Deverill to Warminster due to the heavy rainfall over night.  Areas affected are Longbridge Deverills, Henfords Marsh, Boreham, Water Lane and Norton Bavant.  
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this Warning if necessary.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  People in this area should take action now.  We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 25/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Wylye from Warminster to Wilton
items.message:
River levels are high and rising on the Lower Wylye from Warminster to Wilton
due to the heavy rainfall over night.  Areas affected are Heytesbury, Suffers Bridge, Boyton, Codford St Peter, Wylye and Great Wishford in Wilton.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this Warning if necessary.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  People in this area should take action now.  We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 25/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is affecting low lying land, roads and gardens close to the River Mimram, due to persistent rainfall in December and January, leading to high groundwater levels. 

We are monitoring the flooding that is currently affecting the Fulling Mill Lane, Singlers Marsh, and Codicote Road areas in Welwyn. 

There is elevated risk of flooding caused by water emerging from a third party blocked culvert. Flooding to homes and businesses is unlikely at this time, but there may be a risk to very low-lying properties or those with basements.  River levels in other areas remain below levels of concern. 

The forecast is unsettled for the next 5 days with the potential for blustery showers later in the week. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We are continuing to monitor the situation. 
 
This message will be updated by 5pm, Wednesday 26th February 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Pitton, West Tytherley, Nether Wallop and Broughton
items.message: Groundwater levels remain high. During the last week, almost a month’s rain (45mm) has been recorded at Broughton. At Lopcombe, the level has fallen by 1.12m. At West Tytherley, the level has risen by 18cm. Minor flooding to land, gardens and the sewerage system is possible. From today 24/02/2025, to Friday 28/02/2025, only small amounts of rain are expected. However, there is a small possibility that heavy rain (up to 45mm) may affect the area on Wednesday (26/02/2025). Groundwater levels at Lopcombe are expected to begin rising again in the next few days, in response to rain recorded in the last week. Ongoing flooding impacts will increase and cellar flooding in Nether Wallop may occur. At West Tytherley, the level is expected to continue rising slowly for another week. It is possible that flooding to cellars, land and roads could occur in the village in the next few days. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 03/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Bourne Valley - The Winterbournes
items.message: Groundwater levels in Salisbury Plain remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Winterbourne Gunner, Winterbourne Dauntsey, Winterbourne Earls and Laverstock . The groundwater level at the Queen Manor Farm and Clarendon boreholes are expected to remain high. We are expecting some further rainfall in the coming days, although with low daily totals. We are not currently expecting very much drop in the groundwater levels. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 25/02/2025.

items.description: Rivers Strat and Neet at Helebridge
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected tonight, Sunday 23 February. 

Heavy rain falling in the area will continue overnight. This is causing the Rivers Strat and Neet to rise and the river is forecast to continue rising throughout the night. 

Properties and low lying areas in Helebridge will start to flood first from around 09:30pm tonight. River levels are rising in response to the ongoing rain and are expected to peak in the early hours of Monday morning. 

Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. 

We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated as the situation changes. Our staff are out in the area and will relay information and assist the emergency services and council.
